bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 12, 1921

div1.p: Hanson discusses ways of converting funds into dollars. He reports on field work done by various experts. He mentions funding issues concerning the Peruvian government.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 12, 1921
div1.opener:
Hanson
Sept 12/21
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS
DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
---
OFICINA CENTRAL
-----
Chiclayo, Peru
September 12, 1921.
My Dear Doctor: Carter:
div1.p:
In regard to your letter of July the 18th I think it
will be best for me to attend to the matter of your deposit personally when I
go to Lima next time. I shall be obliged to go down on the first possible oppor-
tunity, which will be after my investigation in Trujillo, probably about the last
week of this month, if steamers are available at that time.

As the exchange is now it is unfortunate that you did not convert this
money at the time. The exchange lately has been down below 3.20 but has shown a
tendency towards improvement lately. I will consult with the best authorities
about what to do in a case like yours. Personally it seems to me that the ex-
change is bound to rise, and it would probably be better to leave what you have
drawing interest until you can convert it to better advantage, in case you are not
in need of this money for the next few months.

Yesterday I sent Guldstrand, Pickett and Dunn south, first to make and
inspection in the Province of Pacasmayo and then to go on to Libertad Trujillo.
Guldstrand to check up on accounts and Pickett and Dunn of the breeding conditions.
I believe Dunn is going to prove a very valuale element in the wind up of this
campaign. He is a good field man in addition to being an entomologist. My diffi-
culty in having him do the investigation which I wanted to do on the stegomya is
that it will be very difficult for him to do this and the inspections too, unless
I give him a limited field in the vicinity of Haucho or some larger place like that
to look after. I wish you would give me your opinion and advise in the matter.

I got a latter from Miss Read this morning telling me to pay myself from
their funds. I did like to do this because I think the Government should be made to
come across with something at least, and I rubbed them pretty hard in the matter in
a letter to the Salubridad, -which I presume will have as much effect as the proverbial
water on a ducks back. I enclose copy of the letter.
